did.abstract: The Nepal Church History Project began in 1985 as an initiative of local church leaders in Nepal to research and collect materials relevant to the history of Christianity among the Nepali peoples. The objective of the Project is to preserve, maintain and update a comprehensive, organized documentary record of the Nepali Church from its inception, and to make available documents and information as appropriate to researchers, students and other interested users.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Nepal Church History Project

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Previously held at the Center for the Study of Christianity in the Non-Western World, University of Edinburgh

accessrestrict.head: Information about Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open to qualified researchers.

prefercite.head: Cite As
prefercite.p: Nepal Church History Project Archives, Record Group No. 215, Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Nepal Church History Project was an initiative of local church leaders in Nepal to research and collect materials relevant to the history of Christianity among the Nepali peoples. It began in 1985 and continues under the chairmanship of Dr Rajendra Rongong of Kathmandu. The objective of the Project is to preserve, maintain and update a comprehensive, organized documentary record of the Nepali Church from its inception, and to make available documents and information as appropriate to researchers, students and other interested users.

The roots of the Nepali Church can be traced back to 19th century Scottish and Scandinavian missionaries working among Nepali migrants in North-East India. As in the 1950s Darjeeling was the base from which Nepali evangelists returned to Nepal, in 1998 it was the venue of the Himalayan Congress of Evangelism (HIM-COE) that gathered Nepali Christian leaders dispersed around the world. Nepali Church evangelism is today concerned to spread the Gospel among Nepalis at home and throughout the Nepali diaspora.

In1951 the Kingdom of Nepal opened its frontiers to the external world. Christians, for the first time in two hundred years, were allowed to settle in the country. Church growth was initially slow, and Christians were vulnerable to social and legal persecution. From a few hundred Nepali Christians in the 1950s and 1960s, their number is now in excess of 300,000. This represents one of the fastest rates of church growth in Asia.

The NCHP documentation was originally located in the Centre for the Study of Christianity in the Non-Western World (CSCNWW), Faculty of Divinity, University of Edinburgh, Scotland. It was there that Dr Cindy Perry, Coordinator of NCHP, conducted her pioneer research on the Nepali Church, the preliminary fruits of which have been published in her Biographical History of the Church in Nepal (Kathmandu: Nepal Church History Project, 1990), and Nepalis Around the World (Kathmandu: RC Timothy, Ekta Books Distributors, 1997).

scopecontent.head: Description of the Papers
scopecontent.p: The collection includes correspondence, reports, and documents relating to the early history of Nepali Church in North India, its development in Nepal since 1951, and its outreach in the wider diaspora countries. It also includes photographs relating to the same three divisions, teaching materials published in Nepal and India by the Nepali Church and by Christian missions, including Bibles and hymnbooks, and published materials, both Christian and secular, relevant to the Nepali Church. The materials have been organized according to a numerical classification system devised by the Project. This finding aid provides an outline of the files. A searchable database that provides document-level description is available at the repository.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Many of these articles have numbers in the Himalayan Collection, Series A.

Titles: Introductory Historical Statement in Visions & Victories in Hindustan by Brenton T. Badley (1931); Chapter II: Naini Tal by N. B. Waugh and M. E. Badley; Chapter XXIV: Pithoragarh by Lucy W. Sullivan; Chapter LVIII: Almora by E. S. Oakley; Things Touching the King: The Story of the Duchess of Teck Hospital by G. W. Emery and M. W. Anderson; A Wonderful Deliverance by J. H. Coombe; Calendar; Caste or Christ? Sketches of Indian life by John Z. Hodge and George E. Hicks (1906); The Cloud Moves by Kenneth Holmes (1974); The Cloud Moves by Kenneth Homes (earlier printing); Via Raxaul; Miscellaneous copied pages; All My Mountains by A. Donald Miller (1961); How They Found Christ by Rebecca J. Parker (1940); Whosoever chapters by Mary Warburten Booth (n.d.); First Fruits of the Forest by Betty Pritchard (n.d.); Willing Outcast by Pat Richards (n.d.); Together They Served: Mr. and Mrs. Fred Merian by Inez Spence (1960); Agnes and Christian Beckdahl On the Borders of Nepal by Inez Spence (n.d.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These materials also have numbers in the Himalayan Collection Series A and F.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Church Growth, Helath, Dynamics, and Strategies, a course at the Australian College of Theology by John Barclay. The supervisor is Bruce Dipple and the subject is "A description and analysis of the growth of the Church in Nepal with reference to relevant Church Growth writings." Also included are some emails between Cynthia Hale, Jonathan Bonk, and Betty Young about Church Growth and an article about Church Growth in Nepal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These materials also have numbers in the Himalayan Collection, Series M.

Titles: Concise Dictionary of the Christian World Mission excerpt by S. Neill, G. Anderson, and J. Goodwin (1971); Religious Liberty in Nepal by Simon Pandey (1996); Reflections of a Missionary in the Himalayas by Cindy Perry (1995); Church and Mission in Nepal: the Development of a Unique Relationship by Cindy Perry (1990); Tribute to a Pioneer: Pastor David Mukhia: A man after God's own heart by Cindy Perry (1991); Bodhartha (n.d.); 2 copies of "Bhai-Tika" and "Tij Braka": A Case Study in the Contextualization of Two Nepali Festivals by Cindy Perry (1990); The Church Where There Is No Church by Cindy L. Perry (1990); Nepal Conversation by Donald McGavran, Cindy Perry, and Henrietta Watson (1989); The Growth of the Church in Nepal with reference to A Hindu Perspective, Inter Faith Dialogue, Aid and Development Issues and Prisons by Jim Robertson (1993); Gospel and Culture by K. B. Rokaya (1996); What If All Nepalis Became Christians? by R. B. Rokaya (1996); Towards a Truelly Nepali Church: Contextualization of the Gospel by K. B. Rokaya (n.d.); Evangelism and Social Concern by K. B. Rokaya (n.d.); Affidavit (n.d.); The Gospel Comes to the Hindu Kingdom by Saubhagya Shah (1993); Peoplesfile Index by Allan Starling (1986); Nepal: Location of Languages A Prayer Guide (1985); Ethnologue Languages of the World by Barbara F. Grimes, Richard S. Pittman, and Joseph E. Grimes (1988); Christian Suffering in Asia: Chapter 13: The Church in Nepal by Nicanor Tamang (1989); That the World May Know: Closed Doors by F. A. Tatford (1983); Mission Handbook - North American Protestant Ministries Overseas excerpt by Samuel Wilson (1980)

scopecontent.p: 1 booklet in a foreign language - probably Nepali. Also, the file contains a letter written by the CEEFI Secretary Diraisingh James (1991).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles: Bible Correspondence Course "Foundations of Faith" translated by Pradeep Pradhan into what looks like Nepalese (n.d.); Foundations of Faith (What The Bible Says): A Discipleship Course for Home Study by Delhi Bible Institute (1984); Nepali translation of DBI follow-up booklet "Everybody Should Know" translated by Pradeep Pradhan (n.d.); 2 copies - Everybody Should Know The Bible and its Message: An Introduction to the study of the Bible by Delhi Bible Institute (n.d.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TAFTEE is The Association for Theological Education by Extension. These materials contain three copies of the Diploma Course - Life of Christ. All three are bound slightly differently and some are longer than others. Also, the file contains some correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles: Bibligoraphy of Christianity in Nepal and the HImalayas (with separate sections on Bhutan, Sikkim, the Nepali Bible and Hymn Books and Archival Sources) by Cindy Perry (n.d.)

Katwal (July, 1986); Himalayan Research Bulletin (Monsoon/Fall, 1985)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains many articles printed from the website nepalnews.com. It also includes an article from the Journal of the Royal Horticultural Society entited "Plant Collecting in Nepal." The final item in the folder is a small orange banner with Bible verses on it from the Winter Gospel Trekking in 1998 as part of the Sikkim Ad 2000 & Beyond movement.
